verses.text: I solemnly charge you before God and Christ Jesus, who will judge the living and the dead, and by his appearing and his kingdom:
verses.comment: Paul invokes the authority and coming judgment of Christ, emphasizing both His divinity and His return as King. This opening solemn charge sets the stage for Timothy’s ministry and echoes the apostolic succession, where authority is passed on through laying of hands (cf. Acts 6:6).

verses.text: Preach the word; be ready in season and out of season; correct, rebuke, and encourage—with all patience and teaching.
verses.comment: Timothy is urged to diligent ministry regardless of circumstances, reflecting the enduring nature of the apostolic mission. The emphasis on ‘teaching’ hints at the importance of sound doctrine passed faithfully, paralleling the tradition preserved by the apostles.

verses.text: For the time will come when people will not put up with sound teaching, but instead will gather teachers to suit their own desires, turning their ears away from the truth.
verses.comment: A prophetic warning of apostasy. Spiritual discernment is needed to hold fast to true teaching, implying reliance upon the community led by legitimate shepherds.

verses.text: They will turn away from listening to the truth and wander into myths.
verses.comment: Paul highlights the danger of doctrinal error. The verse alludes to the necessity for the Church to guard the true faith handed down from the apostles, keeping believers safe from error.

verses.text: But as for you, keep a clear mind in everything, endure hardship, do the work of an evangelist, fulfill your ministry.
verses.comment: Timothy’s call is to persevering ministry and steadfastness, a model for apostolic leadership and faithfulness to the end.

verses.text: For I am already being poured out as a drink offering, and the time of my departure has come.
verses.comment: Paul likens his impending death to a sacrificial offering, echoing Old Testament imagery (Ps. 116:13-14), signifying his union with Christ’s own sacrifice and the value of participating in Christ’s sufferings (cf. Phil. 2:17).

verses.text: I have fought the good fight, I have finished the race, I have kept the faith.
verses.comment: Paul summarizes his life in terms of faithful endurance, which serves as a model for perseverance and completion of one’s spiritual calling.

verses.text: Now there is reserved for me the crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the righteous Judge, will award to me on that day—and not only to me, but also to all who have loved his appearing.
verses.comment: Paul’s hope rests in Christ’s future judgment and reward, offered to all who persevere in love and faith. The ‘crown’ is an image of participation in Christ’s glory, obtained through enduring faith.

verses.text: Make every effort to come to me soon.
verses.comment: Paul expresses deep longing for companionship and support near the end of his life, highlighting the importance of spiritual brotherhood.

verses.text: For Demas, loving this present world, has deserted me and gone to Thessalonica. Crescens has gone to Galatia, and Titus to Dalmatia.
verses.comment: Paul contrasts faithfulness with worldly distractions; Demas’s departure serves as a caution against prioritizing temporal affairs over spiritual commitment.

verses.text: Luke alone is with me. Get Mark and bring him with you, because he is helpful to me in ministry.
verses.comment: Mark's restoration to Paul implies the value of reconciliation within the Church and the ongoing role of trusted co-workers in ministry.

verses.text: I have sent Tychicus to Ephesus.
verses.comment: The sending of Tychicus continues the apostolic practice of delegation, maintaining unity and connection across church communities.

verses.text: When you come, bring the cloak I left with Carpus at Troas, and also the books—especially the parchments.
verses.comment: Paul’s request for books and parchments shows the importance of tradition and learning, essential for teaching and preserving doctrine.

verses.text: Alexander the metalworker did me great harm; the Lord will repay him according to his deeds.
verses.comment: Paul entrusts justice to God, showing that vengeance and judgment belong to the Lord, echoing Christ’s teaching (Rom. 12:19).

verses.text: Watch out for him yourself, for he strongly opposed our message.
verses.comment: Warns Timothy to guard against false teaching and opposition, protecting the purity of the gospel.

verses.text: At my first defense, no one stood with me, but everyone abandoned me. May it not be held against them.
verses.comment: Paul imitates Christ by forgiving those who abandoned him, revealing the power of mercy and a spirit of reconciliation (Luke 23:34).

verses.text: But the Lord stood by me and gave me strength, so that through me the message might be fully proclaimed and all the Gentiles might hear. So I was rescued from the lion’s mouth.
verses.comment: Paul likens his deliverance to Daniel, symbolizing divine protection for those called to proclaim the gospel to the nations (cf. Ps. 22:21, Dan. 6:22).

verses.text: The Lord will rescue me from every evil attack and will bring me safely into his heavenly kingdom. To him be glory forever and ever. Amen.
verses.comment: Paul’s confidence in final salvation echoes Christ’s prayer for His disciples (John 17:24) and points to the hope of believers sharing eternal life in God’s presence.

verses.text: Greet Prisca and Aquila, and the household of Onesiphorus.
verses.comment: Paul’s closing greetings reinforce the importance of familial and communal bonds in the life of the Church.

verses.text: Erastus stayed in Corinth, and I left Trophimus sick in Miletus.
verses.comment: Mentions of sickness and travel highlight the humanity and struggles of early Christians, requiring mutual care and prayer.

verses.text: Do your best to come before winter. Eubulus greets you, as do Pudens, Linus, Claudia, and all the brothers.
verses.comment: The inclusion of Linus, according to historical tradition, signifies continuity of leadership in the church from the apostles (cf. Rom. 16:21).

verses.text: The Lord be with your spirit. Grace be with you.
verses.comment: Paul closes with a prayer for grace and spiritual communion, expressing the Church's abiding presence and unity in Christ through the spirit.
